content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I enjoyed solving this.

Looking through other comments, it appears that there were some issues that would have held this back for me, especially in a reverse setting (Names/proper nouns being uppercase). However, this was fun to solve, and didn't need the statement.

Simple, easy to understand, and fun

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Easy clash, but complex enough to be satisfying.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A fun exercise and not too difficult.

Hello ! I have feedback to give you to accept your proposal : change the title, it gives the response.

Have a good day !
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
nice

Nice! At first I thought it was too easy based off of the puzzle title but it turned out to have a moderate level of complexity for a quick reverse puzzle. Maybe try to change the title that gives the puzzle away. Good work!
Creative, indeed
Creative
nice one tbh

Updated the contribution:

1. Proper names and nouns are removed, so we can treat all capitalized words the same.
2. Tricky punctuation like "In _that_ direction" is removed.

I hope than now you will not struggle with the puzzle too much.

Maybe I even made it too easy, I'm afraid... But you decide.

Hello everyone,

Thank you all for great feedback!

I will review the puzzle at weekend and rework it in such a way that people will not struggle with the logic too much.
I agree with the Capital word issues. I managed to solve it but struggled with the capitals. Others have put forward valid changes and suggestions. Otherwise, very good contribution

If this is Reverse only, then you should remove all the explanation so that reviewers can test it under Reverse conditions and see if it's solvable.

I just tried it myself without reading the description and I solved most of it, but couldn't understand the logic behind why "Hello," -> "Hello-hello," but "Cat" -> "Cat-Cat" and "Alice" -> "Alice-Alice". I don't think you should try to encode a decision of whether a word is a proper noun or not into a clash, especially not a Reverse one.

What would happen if the sentence started with "Alice", how would you know whether it's capitalised due to being the first word or due to being a proper noun? I think you should just treat all capitalised words the same, as Stef_3 said. So the "Complex case" tests need to be adjusted.

I suggest the following simplifications:
- Treat all capitalised words the same, regardless of whether they are capitalised because they are the first word in a sentence or because they are a proper noun. So, "Hello world" -> "Hello-hello world-world" and "Hello Mr Cat" -> "Hello-hello Mr-mr Cat-cat"
- Guarantee that punctuation can only be at the end of a word, not at the beginning, so "Hello, world!" is allowed but "In _that_ direction" is not allowed.
- Output the doubled words space-separated, not newline-separated; it was much prettier and satisfying this way. Now with the newlines it doesn't look like sentences.

This way, there are exactly two things to take care of: capitals at the beginning of the word, and punctuation at the end of the word.
Added a word splitting (each doubled word on its own line) to address an issue pointed out by Stef_3.
For easy version use only lowercase letters a,b,...,z?

On the "Complex case" I got a failure but I can't distinguish my output from the expected output so there is no way to know what to fix:

`
Found:
"In-in _that-that_ direction-di...either you-you like-like: they-they are-are both-both mad-mad."

Expected:
"In-in _that-that_ direction-di...either you-you like-like: they-they are-are both-both mad-mad."
`
a bit too hard

Alluvial, I understand your concern.

Initially I thought that it will be an easy puzzle, but it turned out that natural languages have many complexities.

At least I tried to simplify it as much as possible while still taking to account the most common language forms.

And I hope that even if you not get 100% score for this puzzle, you at least will enjoy the time spent while solving this puzzle.

Interesting, perhaps there is difference in middle and it cannot be seen because the middle is cut out.

Thank you much for feedback! I will think how to work around this issue.

For reference, full text of complex case (as of time of writing) is:

"In _that_ direction," the Cat said, waving its right paw round, "lives a Hatter: and in _that_ direction," waving the other paw, "lives a March Hare. Visit either you like: they are both mad."

And the expected result is:

"In-in _that-that_ direction-direction," the-the Cat-Cat said-said, waving-waving its-its right-right paw-paw round-round, "lives-lives a-a Hatter-Hatter: and-and in-in _that-that_ direction-direction," waving-waving the-the other-other paw-paw, "lives-lives a-a March-March Hare-Hare. Visit-visit either-either you-you like-like: they-they are-are both-both mad-mad."

Hello, Pyth1,

Thanks for the suggestion, but I'm afraid that this will be too easy:

C:\Users\Aksima>echo "hello, world!" | perl -ne "s/(\w+)/\1-\1/g; print;"
"hello-hello, world-world!"

You will simply lose such clash to those having higher typing speed.

Hello, gabitho788,

I cannot think of any better title. What title do you suggest?

Please do not post solutions here.

This topic is for suggestions for improvements and asking questions, not for posting solutions.

And there are the reference solution anyway (I guess you can see it with 50+ clashes played).
I think I finally got an idea. Changed the title from "Double the words" to "Twin words", so that the title does not directly tell you what to do.

Thanks ! I will upvote your proposal.
Have a good day !
Hello! I think, for a 5 min exercise that it's a bit difficult : wouldn't it be better if you remove the ponctuation and/or the upper-case letter ?
There already was a lot of simplifications to the exercise, so I think it have a proper difficulty level now.
Ok ! I will accept your proposal.

Yes, the issue is that I don't duplicate capitals, so I write Cat-cat instead of Cat-Cat, but there is no way to see that you expect Cat-Cat in the puzzle since it's hidden in the ... part (and the Hello from "Hello world" becomes Hello-hello, not Hello-Hello)

"Cat" is in a middle of sentence, and is still capitalized, so this means that this is a proper noun.

Proper noun must remain capitalized even if doubled. You do not want your name to be written with a small letter, do you?

On the contrary, "Hello" in "Hello, world!", is just a greeting, not someone's name.
Yes, I understand that. Because I can see the testcases on this page. But from the IDE page when solving the puzzle there is no way to see that. There are no visible "proper nouns" in the tests.
Understood. I will think how to work around this limitation. Thank you for pointing that out!
Stef_3, I think that issue with unclear error message should be fixed now. Check it out.
